Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: BIO IUSE Ideas Lab: Supporting Faculty in Quantitative Undergraduate Biology Education and Synthesis (QUBES)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
With funding from the National Science Foundation's Improving Undergraduate STEM Education (IUSE) program, this project addresses the Nation's growing need to better prepare undergraduate biologists with the quantitative and computational skills needed to be successful in the workplace or in graduate school. The full integration of mathematical reasoning skills into undergraduate biology classrooms has been challenging, in part, because of the rapid pace of change in many biological disciplines and an academic reward system that often overlooks pedagogical development and research.

The Supporting Faculty in Quantitative Undergraduate Biology Education and Synthesis (QUBES) project involves five interdependent initiatives that promote the integration of quantitative and computational skills across the biological sciences curriculum. The project is building on the investments of existing communities by coordinating the efforts and resources of diverse groups that are already involved in quantitative biology education reform. This approach allows QUBES to amplify the strengths of organizations like professional societies and specialized curriculum projects while streamlining the communications and coordination required to grow broader community of reform-minded faculty educators in quantitative biology (QB). Mentoring networks will be used to support faculty understanding and classroom implementation of specific quantitative biology concepts and teaching strategies. These mentoring networks will be led by teams containing both quantitative and pedagogical expertise and will serve spatially distributed groups of instructors who share a common interest in reforming their current teaching practices. Participating instructors will disseminate resources within their own institutions, organize new mentoring networks, and take leadership roles in their professional societies. The products from these collaborations will be captured as part of the QUBES Hub, a virtual environment providing professional support activities and access to curriculum resources for all QB educators. In order to address the challenges of documenting teaching scholarship, the QUBES project is also piloting a system for describing and tracking faculty contributions to the QB education community. This high-risk, but potentially transformative, initiative to develop meaningful metrics of teaching scholarship could have a long term impact on academic reward systems across diverse institution types. By strengthening QB research and development tools, the project is enriching the discipline and catalyzing long-term academic cultural change across STEM education. Finally, the collaborative is studying and disseminating what they learn about the effectiveness of this educational reform effort. This research will take a systems approach to characterize effective interventions and barriers to change within the complex landscape of factors influencing the success of educational reform.

The efficient execution and management of a project with this level of complexity requires thorough and ongoing evaluation. The project team is embedding data collection systems throughout project activities as a means to track progress in near real time, manage resources effectively, and maintain clear communication across connected project components. The QUBES approach to implementation, research, and development promises to have a significant impact on QB education across the nation and, more generally, to inform systemic STEM education reform efforts.

This project is funded jointly by the Directorate for Biological Sciences and the Directorate of Education and Human Resources, Division of Undergraduate Education in support of efforts to address the challenges posed in Vision and Change in Undergraduate Education: A Call to Action http://visionandchange.org/finalreport/

POR.DRECONTENT:
Biological research has become increasingly quantitative with the development of more sophisticated statistics and mathematical modeling, access to massive data sets, and growth in computational power.  As a result, the development of quantitative skills is critical to undergraduate student success across biology disciplines from molecular biology to ecology.  Furthermore, these skills are an important aspect of workforce development, preparing students for a wide array of science and technology careers. The range of quantitative skills which should be introduced as part of an undergraduate biology curriculum include data analysis and interpretation, statistical inference, and competency with basic computational tools. In order to effectively incorporate these quantitative skills faculty need educational resources and professional development that combine effective pedagogical approaches and current quantitative practices.  The Quantitative Undergraduate Biology Education and Synthesis (QUBES) project is designed to support undergraduate biology faculty teaching quantitative skills by providing professional development access to high quality educational resources within a supportive community of peers. Over 7000 educators from across the country, at large and small campuses, two and four year colleges, R1s and liberal arts institutions have come together over the past six years to develop and learn about new educational materials. Faculty at all career stages have found a place in the QUBES community sharing ideas and resources, and supporting one another in the goal of improving quantitative biology education. 

 

In addition to individual faculty members, almost 100 education reform projects, many funded by NSF or supported by professional societies, are partners in the QUBES community. Partnering with QUBES contributes to the impacts and sustainability of these projects through professional development experiences that engage new participants in projects, dissemination of project materials, and the collaborative generation of new and updated educational resources. Resources are shared in the QUBES community in a variety of ways including the newsletter and social media, through project websites, and in structured professional development experiences. QUBES also contributes to the sustainability of projects by hosting projects beyond their funding period, facilitating updates of existing materials, and promoting the publication of resources as open education resources (OERs).  OERs reduce accessibility barriers for students, and provide faculty with flexibility to modify materials for their own classrooms.  QUBES has a simple, elegant system that makes publishing, accessing, and modifying OERs simple for users. In addition, this publication system helps faculty receive credit for their efforts in developing educational materials as the publication system provides a permanent DOI (digital object identifier) and citation for CVs, as well as user metrics.  

 

The intellectual merit of the QUBES project lies in accelerating the adoption of evidence based teaching practices to improve educational experiences, and advancing the scholarship of teaching.  QUBES provides a variety of professional development opportunities, including Faculty Mentoring Networks, a peer group professional development experience, Incubators, a facilitated work space for curriculum development, and Working Groups, organized peer groups designed to explore key issues in quantitative biology education. All of these professional development experiences are offered virtually and while the project has been funded by NSF, free of charge, reducing barriers to participation presented by time constraints, lack of funds, and teaching commitments.  QUBES staff support education project leaders who wish to disseminate their materials through these professional development programs, so that materials and practices are brought to the community by experienced mentors.  Professional development experiences in QUBES also engage faculty with their peers for an extended period of time, facilitating the development of new materials and supporting faculty through the challenges presented in implementing new materials or practices.  QUBES creates broader impacts in teaching through its emphasis on inclusive and accessible teaching practices. Taking a ?train the trainer? approach, QUBES has worked with education project leaders to promote equity, diversity, and inclusive practices in the development of new materials, and support the incorporation of these ideas in QUBES based professional development experiences.  

 

QUBES is a collaboration between four academic institutions (the University of Pittsburgh, College of William and Mary, Radford University, and Bates College) and a non-profit education group (BioQUEST Curriculum Consortium) and arose from an NSF Ideas Lab in 2014.  The QUBES project reflects the Science Gateway model in which cyberinfrastructure is designed to support a user community, such as researchers, educators, or students. Gateways provide convenient access to tools, applications, and data that is relevant to the community?s activities. QUBESHub is the project?s cyberinfrastructure on a customized HubZero site, which has been modified extensively to better serve the community.  The project has successfully achieved the proposed goals of building community, providing virtual professional development experiences, and building a customized platform for community activities.  The project is well positioned to provide metrics about participation and use of resources, and to support the generation and use of OERs, as well as promoting equitable and inclusive teaching practices across the community.
